repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Things like match-case (essentially anything that uses Python's
new PEG parser capacities) are going to have to be implemented
by trying to parse something, failing, then going back and trying
to parse something else. This commit gets the initial work done
to make this easier to do.

Present without really being used (but with some tests) in the hope that it can be merged sooner and so won't have to go into a huge commit when it's actually useful.

For the moment the main visible change is that that position is more accurately restored after `s.put_back`.

comment_data.body: We could store the dot positions in a separate list and zip both lists together here. Not very costly, I'd say.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2763,10 +2767,10 @@ def looking_at_expr(s):
 
         dotted_path.reverse()
         for p in dotted_path:
-            s.put_back(u'IDENT', p)
-            s.put_back(u'.', u'.')
+            s.put_back(u'IDENT', *p)
+            s.put_back(u'.', u'.', p[1])  # gets the position slightly wrong

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    #
    #  These positions are used to track what was read from the queue
```

     #  start_line = 0        # line number of start of token
     #  start_col = 0         # position in line of start of token
+    #  These positions are used to track what was read from the queue

comment_data.body: You have just added this method to Plex, so this comment is outdated.

                     self.produce(value)
-        result = queue[0]
+        result, result_pos = queue[0]
+        self.last_token_line, self.last_token_col = result_pos
         del queue[0]
         return result
 
+    def unread(self, token, value, pos_line, pos_col):
+        # This method should be added to Plex

comment_data.body:
This seems unnecessarily complex and unclear.
```suggestion
        self.unread(self.sy, self.systring, next_pos[1], next_pos[2])
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -462,20 +469,21 @@ def next(self):
 
     def peek(self):
         saved = self.sy, self.systring
+        saved_pos = self.position()
         self.next()
         next = self.sy, self.systring
-        self.unread(*next)
+        next_pos = self.position()
+        self.unread(*(next+next_pos[1:]))

comment_data.body:
Looks like these could just be stored as a tuple. Looking at the usage, maybe not even a ctuple but a plain Python tuple.

However, why wasn't it an option to reset `start_line` and `start_col` instead of adding new attributes?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -61,10 +63,14 @@ class Scanner(object):
     #  start_pos = 0         # position in input of start of token
     #  start_line = 0        # line number of start of token
     #  start_col = 0         # position in line of start of token
+    #  These positions are used to track what was read from the queue
+    #   (which may differ from the internal state when tokens are replaced onto the queue)
+    #  last_token_line       # line number of the last token taken from the queue
+    #  last_token_col        # position in line of the last token taken from the queue

comment_data.body:
There's the `strings` module in the stdlib.
```suggestion
for ch in strings.ascii_letters:
    line = " ".join(["%s%s" % (ch, n) for n in range(10)])
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,104 @@
+from __future__ import unicode_literals
+
+import unittest
+from io import StringIO
+
+from Cython.Compiler import Scanning
+from Cython.Compiler.Symtab import ModuleScope
+from Cython.Compiler.TreeFragment import StringParseContext
+from Cython.Compiler.Errors import init_thread
+
+# generate some fake code - just a bunch of lines of the form "a0 a1 ..."
+code = []
+for ch in range(ord("a"), ord("z")):
+    line = " ".join(["%s%s" % (chr(ch), n) for n in range(10)])

comment_data.body:
The comment suggests that this should never be called with a position argument. And scanner errors would always seem fatal.
Also, maybe `error_at_scanpos` might be a more descriptive name than `error_in_action`. And could probably also be added to `Scanning.pxd` as a `cdef` method.
```suggestion
    def error_in_action(self, message):
        # Like error(fatal=True), but gets the current scanning position rather than
        # the position of the last token read.
        pos = (self.name, self.start_line, self.start_col)
        self.error(message, pos)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -485,6 +493,13 @@ def error(self, message, pos=None, fatal=True):
         err = error(pos, message)
         if fatal: raise err
 
+    def error_in_action(self, message, pos=None, fatal=True):
+        # like error, but gets the current scanning position rather than
+        # the position of the last token read
+        if pos is None:
+            pos = (self.name, self.start_line, self.start_col)
+        self.error(message, pos, fatal)

comment_data.body: I'd like to ignore this comment specifically because (a) it's only a small off-by-one error, and (b) I'm pretty sure I can get rid of this whole `looking_at_expr` function as a next step. So it doesn't really seem worth fixing here.

comment_data.body:
I've combined the two comments:
* got rid of `last_token_line`, `last_token_col`, `start_line` and `start_col`
* converted it to a tuple (with all three position elements in it - although the filename doesn't change it seems easier to make it part of the tuple)

commit.message:
Initial work to help restore Scanner state

Things like match-case (essentially anything that uses Python's
new PEG parser capacities) are going to have to be implemented
by trying to parse something, failing, then going back and trying
to parse something else. This commit gets the initial work done
to make this easier to do
Fix error string locations in text
Fix a few mistakes in pxd file
Add back in separate scanning position

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

title: Make it easier to restore state during parsing phase
